1.text: Lo, mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and understood it.

2.text: What ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you.

3.text: Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.

4.text: But ye are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.

5.text: O that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.

6.text: Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.

7.text: Will ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?

8.text: Will ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?

9.text: Is it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him?

10.text: He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.

11.text: Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?

12.text: Your remembrances are like unto ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.

13.text: Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.

14.text: Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in mine hand?

15.text: Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain mine own ways before him.

16.text: He also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrite shall not come before him.

17.text: Hear diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.

18.text: Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.

19.text: Who is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall give up the ghost.

20.text: Only do not two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.

21.text: Withdraw thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.

22.text: Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.

23.text: How many are mine iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgression and my sin.

24.text: Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thine enemy?

25.text: Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?

26.text: For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.

27.text: Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heels of my feet.

28.text: And he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth eaten.
